Comments: Was this review helpful to you?
Reviews:
OVERALL
A very good headset for the price. Caveat, the price varies considerably, even on Amazon.com, often from hour-to-hour. I purchased a new set for $9 from Amazon.

COMFORTABILITY
"Behind-the-neck" headphones are generally the most comfortable type you can purchase. However, you can buy a half-dozen different headsets which look identical except for the brandname. Some will be comfortable, some won't. Apparently different folks have different shaped heads and ears, which is important to the fit of behind-the-neck headphones. So, when you find a set which is comfortable for you---buy an extra set or two and stash them. Personally, I find the Sony MDR-G45LP headphones to be very comfortable---but your experience could be different.

ADJUSTABILTIY
Like all other "behind-the-neck" headphones Sony MDR-G45LPs are non-adjustable because no adjustment is necessary. In fact, that is one of the advantages of "behind-the-neck" headsets as compared to "top-of-the-head" headsets.

CORD LENGTH
Despite the silly complaints of a few other reviewers that the cord is short, it is in fact the Sony MDR-G45LP cord is the standard length---long enough for you to carry your MP3 in your pants pocket. Short is better than too long---you can always add a cheap extension, for example Cables To Go 40405 3.5 mm Male/Female Stereo Audio Extension Cable, Black (1.5 Feet/0.45 Meters). If the cord is too long, it will catch on things, straining the cord at the plug----which is what will ultimately kill the headset.

SOUND QUALITY
The sound quality of the Sony MDR-G45LPs is VERY crisp and clear, (unlike many headsets which are optimized to "pump up the bass" which makes voice and treble muddy). I use the headphones to listen to audiobooks for which it is perfect.

CONSTRUCTION QUALITY
Appears to be good, but unfortunately, the Sony MDR-G45LP has a right-angle plug. Virtually all headsets "die" by strain on the wires at the plugs---so straight plugs are far better than angled plugs (because straight plugs pull out easily, rather than straining the wire).

COMPARISON WITH OTHER TYPES OF HEADPHONES

"Behind-the-neck" headphones are generally the most comfortable type you can purchase. They also the best at staying in place when exercising.

For an "outside the house/office" headset, I prefer my J-buds JBuds Hi-Fi Noise-Reducing Ear Buds (White) with my Budkeeper Carrying Case - Fire Engine Red (BKFD20-G47) case, which I clip to a belt loop. I can also stash a couple of extra AAA batteries with my J-Buds in the Budkeeper. The J-Buds in the Budkeeper are a much smaller package, and J-Buds are better at noise reduction, for example in a doctor's waiting room with a TV on. However earbuds can become uncomfortable after several hours. I suspect that the build-up of heat and moisture in your ear canals might lead to infections if earbuds are worn several hours daily. Indeed, enough heat builds up to melt your earwax, which then solidifies in and on the earbuds. Premium earbuds even have replaceable "wax filters". If you wear non-premium earbuds, clean the earwax out regularly, or it will get to the speakers and kill them.

"Top of the head" headphones slip easily, require adjustment, interfere with wearing hats and interfere with women wearing hair "up". The only purpose for which a "top-of-the-head" headset is better, is for listening to music while taking a nap.

Apple/airline type earplugs are just plain uncomfortable, fall out of your ears easily, and do not provide the noise isolation of earbuds.

I got these as my running headphones. After owning some $40 Sennheiser headphones for years now, I've learned what good, low-cost headphones sound like. These are not good low-cost headphones. There's an area between subwoofer and mid-range where things are too quiet - the headphones can't really put sound out well in this range. The sound in general is a little tinny and scratchy. The combination ends up adding up to a disappointing sound when listening to any recorded voice, because it typically has been put through that kind of mic processing to have that deep male radio voice, right in the range these headphones are worst.

All of that said, the sound isn't terrible, it's just subpar. You'd think Sony could produce headphones in the same quality range as Sennheiser for a similar price, and based on what I know about headphones - it's a difference of a few cents for the manufacturer to get that right, so they're making crappy headphones to avoid competing with their more expensive products. Very lame.

There's also an issue when running with these. I wear glasses - pretty light ones, which are nice for running. The way these clip around my ear can sometimes cause them to slowly wedge themselves beneath the stems on my glasses, causing them to bounce around while running - a very dizzying experience. However, on a few runs I've been able to gradually adjust them to prevent that - basically if I set them back a little farther on my ear than where they'd naturally sit, they seem to stay in place just far enough above the stems that they don't cause issues. So far.

In addition, the sound quality is so-so, even for myself with limited hearing. I really don't expect much at all in the way of sound quality from headphones due to my hearing loss and, given the inexpensive nature of these headphones, perhaps that is the reason for the less than decent sound quality. Thing is, I have another pair of Sony headphones that cost all of about $15 more and they are terrific in terms of sound quality, so I'm not so sure it's a function of price.

In any case, for the price these headphones are fine. The cord length is good and the headphones themselves are quite lightweight. For the price, not a bad pair of headphones - just not quite the fit I need.

Title: I've Never Had a Pair Last More than a Year

Comments: One person found this helpful. Was this review helpful to you?
Reviews:
The Street Style MDRG45LP is just what my husband needed for his rather large cranium. The behind the neck design is the only option the feels comfortable. He has tried ear buds and they result in either always falling out or when in for longer than 20-mins result in ear pain. The behind the neck design of the Street Style provides a comfortable solution for those grocery store visits.

The physical design is sturdy and provide enough flexibility to be adjustable without fear of breaking them. The padding on over the speakers are a typical foam that provides a level of comfort. The on-ear design allows for clearly being able to hear both your audio of choice but also the world around you except of higher volumes.

These are wired and come with a long enough cable to allow for use of an audio source in your pocket. The end is equipped with a 1/8“audio jack which is a perfect pair for most mobile devices. The connector has a 90-degree angle at the end. I like this touch as it feels like it will have less of a chance or kinking while in a pocket. I did have some issues getting it to sit just right in my iPhone 6. If I pushed it too far in it would sound very low and distant. If I pull it out just a bit and make proper contact it worked like a charm. We have been through several headphones/ear buds and never had this prior.

Sound quality is decent, considering this price point. (currently $15.62) It has a fair base response and the high were adequate. My source for testing was Amazon music streaming and some pod cast. I know these are not the best sources but also consider that this is what my husband uses this for. That being said, the base is ample however lacks accuracy. The highs are strong and match pretty well to the strength of the base tones. It’s the mid-range that suffers the most. Vocals can be muffled at time depending on the music. Pod casts work very well as any vocal bas tones augment this short fall.

Pros:
• Solid construction
• Fits well for those with a large dome
• Wired so you never have to charge them and can keep them in your car
• Great value

Cons:
• Sound quality is adequate. There are better sounding headphones however for this price point this is the best by far.

Conclusion:

This may sound like a bad review but it is quite the contrary. The Street Style MDRG45LP headphone is comfortable, durable and provides good sound quality for this price point. I gave it 4 stars because of the price for performance. Subtle changes that would have me up it to 5 stars would be to flatten the response to allow the mid-range to open vocals. That being said I have yet to find anything better at this price point.
